trans-unit.source: DSC Configurations
trans-unit.target: DSC Configurations

trans-unit.source: Applies To: Windows PowerShell 4.0, Windows PowerShell 5.0
trans-unit.target: Applies To: Windows PowerShell 4.0, Windows PowerShell 5.0

trans-unit.source: DSC configurations are PowerShell scripts that define a special type of function.
trans-unit.target: DSC configurations are PowerShell scripts that define a special type of function.

trans-unit.source: To define a configuration, you use the PowerShell keyword Configuration.
trans-unit.target: To define a configuration, you use the PowerShell keyword Configuration.

trans-unit.source: Save the script as a .ps1 file.
trans-unit.target: Save the script as a .ps1 file.

trans-unit.source: Configuration syntax
trans-unit.target: Configuration syntax

trans-unit.source: A configuration script consists of the following parts:
trans-unit.target: A configuration script consists of the following parts:

trans-unit.source: The Configuration block.
trans-unit.target: The Configuration block.

trans-unit.source: This is the outermost script block.
trans-unit.target: This is the outermost script block.

trans-unit.source: You define it by using the Configuration keyword and providing a name.
trans-unit.target: You define it by using the Configuration keyword and providing a name.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the name of the configuration is "MyDscConfiguration".
trans-unit.target: In this case, the name of the configuration is "MyDscConfiguration".

trans-unit.source: One or more Node blocks.
trans-unit.target: One or more Node blocks.

trans-unit.source: These define the nodes (computers or VMs) that you are configuring.
trans-unit.target: These define the nodes (computers or VMs) that you are configuring.

trans-unit.source: In the above configuration, there is one Node block that targets a computer named "TEST-PC1".
trans-unit.target: In the above configuration, there is one Node block that targets a computer named "TEST-PC1".

trans-unit.source: One or more resource blocks.
trans-unit.target: One or more resource blocks.

trans-unit.source: This is where the configuration sets the properties for the resources that it is configuring.
trans-unit.target: This is where the configuration sets the properties for the resources that it is configuring.

trans-unit.source: In this case, there are two resource blocks, each of which call the "WindowsFeature" resource.
trans-unit.target: In this case, there are two resource blocks, each of which call the "WindowsFeature" resource.

trans-unit.source: Within a Configuration block, you can do anything that you normally could in a PoweShell function.
trans-unit.target: Within a Configuration block, you can do anything that you normally could in a PoweShell function.

trans-unit.source: For example, in the previous example, if you didn't want to hard code the name of the target computer in the configuration, you could add a parameter for the node name:
trans-unit.target: For example, in the previous example, if you didn't want to hard code the name of the target computer in the configuration, you could add a parameter for the node name:

trans-unit.source: In this example, you specify the name of the node by passing it as the $computerName parameter when you [compile the configuraton](# Compiling the configuration).
trans-unit.target: In this example, you specify the name of the node by passing it as the $computerName parameter when you [compile the configuraton](# Compiling the configuration).

trans-unit.source: The name defaults to "localhost".
trans-unit.target: The name defaults to "localhost".

trans-unit.source: Compiling the configuration
trans-unit.target: Compiling the configuration

trans-unit.source: Before you can enact a configuration, you have to compile it into a MOF document.
trans-unit.target: Before you can enact a configuration, you have to compile it into a MOF document.

trans-unit.source: You do this by calling the configuration like you would a PowerShell function.
trans-unit.target: You do this by calling the configuration like you would a PowerShell function.

trans-unit.source: Note: To call a configuration, the function must be in global scope (as with any other PowerShell function).
trans-unit.target: Note: To call a configuration, the function must be in global scope (as with any other PowerShell function).

trans-unit.source: You can make this happen either by "dot-sourcing" the script, or by running the configuration script by using F5 or clicking on the Run Script button in the ISE.
trans-unit.target: You can make this happen either by "dot-sourcing" the script, or by running the configuration script by using F5 or clicking on the Run Script button in the ISE.

trans-unit.source: To dot-source the script, run the command `.
trans-unit.target: To dot-source the script, run the command `.

trans-unit.source: .\myConfig.ps1 where myConfig.ps1` is the name of the script file that contains your configuration.
trans-unit.target: .\myConfig.ps1 where myConfig.ps1` is the name of the script file that contains your configuration.

trans-unit.source: When you call the configuration, it creates:
trans-unit.target: When you call the configuration, it creates:

trans-unit.source: A folder in the current directory with the same name as the configuration.
trans-unit.target: A folder in the current directory with the same name as the configuration.

trans-unit.source: A file named NodeName.mof in the new directory, where NodeName is the name of the target node of the configuration.
trans-unit.target: A file named NodeName.mof in the new directory, where NodeName is the name of the target node of the configuration.

trans-unit.source: If there are more than one nodes, a MOF file will be created for each node.
trans-unit.target: If there are more than one nodes, a MOF file will be created for each node.

trans-unit.source: Note: The MOF file contains all of the configuration information for the target node.
trans-unit.target: Note: The MOF file contains all of the configuration information for the target node.

trans-unit.source: Because of this, it’s important to keep it secure.
trans-unit.target: Because of this, it’s important to keep it secure.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Securing the MOF file</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Securing the MOF file</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Compiling the first configuration above results in the following folder structure:
trans-unit.target: Compiling the first configuration above results in the following folder structure:

trans-unit.source: If the configuration takes a parameter, as in the second example, that has to be provided at compile time.
trans-unit.target: If the configuration takes a parameter, as in the second example, that has to be provided at compile time.

trans-unit.source: Here's how that would look:
trans-unit.target: Here's how that would look:

trans-unit.source: Using DependsOn
trans-unit.target: Using DependsOn

trans-unit.source: A useful DSC keyword is DependsOn.
trans-unit.target: A useful DSC keyword is DependsOn.

trans-unit.source: Typically (though not necessarily always), DSC applies the resources in the order that they appear within the configuration.
trans-unit.target: Typically (though not necessarily always), DSC applies the resources in the order that they appear within the configuration.

trans-unit.source: However, DependsOn specifies which resources depend on other resources, and the LCM ensures that they are applied in the correct order, regardless of the order in which resource instances are defined.
trans-unit.target: However, DependsOn specifies which resources depend on other resources, and the LCM ensures that they are applied in the correct order, regardless of the order in which resource instances are defined.

trans-unit.source: For example, a configuration might specify that an instance of the User resource depends on the existence of a Group instance:
trans-unit.target: For example, a configuration might specify that an instance of the User resource depends on the existence of a Group instance:

trans-unit.source: Using New Resources in Your Configuration
trans-unit.target: Using New Resources in Your Configuration

trans-unit.source: If you ran the previous examples, you might have noticed that you were warned that you were using a resource without explicitly importing it.
trans-unit.target: If you ran the previous examples, you might have noticed that you were warned that you were using a resource without explicitly importing it.

trans-unit.source: Today, DSC ships with 12 resources as part of the PSDesiredStateConfiguration module.
trans-unit.target: Today, DSC ships with 12 resources as part of the PSDesiredStateConfiguration module.

trans-unit.source: Other resources in external modules must be placed in $env:PSModulePath in order to be recognized by the LCM.
trans-unit.target: Other resources in external modules must be placed in $env:PSModulePath in order to be recognized by the LCM.

trans-unit.source: A new cmdlet, <linkText>Get-DscResource</linkText><title></title>, can be used to determine what resources are installed on the system and available for use by the LCM.
trans-unit.target: A new cmdlet, <linkText>Get-DscResource</linkText><title></title>, can be used to determine what resources are installed on the system and available for use by the LCM.

trans-unit.source: Once these modules have been placed in $env:PSModulePath and are properly recognized by Get-DscResource, they still need to be loaded within your configuration.
trans-unit.target: Once these modules have been placed in $env:PSModulePath and are properly recognized by Get-DscResource, they still need to be loaded within your configuration.

trans-unit.source: Import-DscResource is a dynamic keyword that can only be recognized within a Configuration block (i.e. it is not a cmdlet).
trans-unit.target: Import-DscResource is a dynamic keyword that can only be recognized within a Configuration block (i.e. it is not a cmdlet).

trans-unit.source: Import-DscResource supports two parameters:
trans-unit.target: Import-DscResource supports two parameters:

trans-unit.source: ModuleName is the recommended way of using Import-DscResource.
trans-unit.target: ModuleName is the recommended way of using Import-DscResource.

trans-unit.source: It accepts the name of the module that contains the resources to be imported (as well as a string array of module names).
trans-unit.target: It accepts the name of the module that contains the resources to be imported (as well as a string array of module names).

trans-unit.source: Name is the name of the resource to import.
trans-unit.target: Name is the name of the resource to import.

trans-unit.source: This is not the friendly name returned as “Name” by Get-DscResource, but the class name used when defining the resource schema (returned as ResourceType by Get-DscResource).
trans-unit.target: This is not the friendly name returned as “Name” by Get-DscResource, but the class name used when defining the resource schema (returned as ResourceType by Get-DscResource).
